others.Description: Do you know what scalability really is? It's a mathematical function that's simple, precise, and useful. REALLY useful. It describes the relationship between system performance and load. In this talk you'll learn the function (the Universal Scalability Law), how it describes and predicts system behavior you see every day, and how to use it in practice. I'll show you how to understand the function, how to capture the data you need to measure your own system's behavior (you probably already have that), and how to analyze the data with the USL. You'll leave this talk knowing exactly what scalability is and what causes non-linear scaling. There are two factors, and you'll start seeing those everywhere, too. As a result, when systems don't scale you'll know what kind of problem to look for, and you'll avoid building bottlenecks into your systems in the first place. Final note: this talk requires zero mathematical skill.
others.Name: LISA17 - Scalability Is Quantifiable: The Universal Scalability Law
others.Resource: LISA17 - Scalability Is Quantifiable: The Universal Scalability Law - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lZU6RK0oazM

others.Name: DOES17 London - The Key to High Performance What the Data Says
others.Resource: DOES17 London - The Key to High Performance What the Data Says - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cabzxfM_vWE

others.Name: DOES17 London - The Key to High Performance What the Data Says
others.Resource: DOES17 London - The Key to High Performance What the Data Says - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cabzxfM_vWE

others.Description: Tom highlights radical ideas from _The Practice of Cloud System Administration_ on embracing failure to build resilient distributed systems, focusing on economic resiliency, performing risky procedures frequently, and creating a blameless culture.
others.Name: Fail Better: Radical Ideas from the Practice of Cloud Computing
others.Resource: Fail Better: Radical Ideas from the Practice of Cloud Computing - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nsrzWEHEWDw

others.Description: Mind the Product San Francisco 2017. A classic one to escape from the feature factory mindset.
others.Name: Escaping the Build Trap
others.Resource: Escaping the Build Trap - https://vimeo.com/224453335

others.Description: This talk is not only very funny, it is also a great description of the problems generated by a "classic" operations mindset and how to change to a modern approach / devops.

others.Description:
Whether it’s distributing configurations and customer settings, launching instances, or responding to surges in load, having a great control plane is key to the success of any system or service. Come hear about the techniques we use to build stable and scalable control planes at Amazon. We dive deep into the designs that power the most reliable systems at AWS. We share hard-earned operational lessons and explain academic control theory in easy-to-apply patterns and principles that are immediately useful in your own designs.
A must to learn how to design Control Panels.
others.Name: AWS re:Invent 2018: Close Loops & Opening Minds: How to Take Control of Systems, Big & Small ARC337
others.Resource: AWS re:Invent 2018: Close Loops & Opening Minds: How to Take Control of Systems, Big & Small ARC337 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O8xLxNje30M

others.Description: Cloud! Autoscaling! Kubernetes! Etc! In theory, it's easier than ever to scale a service based on variable demand. In practice, it's still hard to take observed metrics, and translate them into quantitative predictions about what will happen to service performance as load changes. Resource limits are often chosen by guesstimation, and teams are likely to find themselves reacting to slowdowns and bottlenecks, rather than anticipating them. Queueing theory can help, by treating large-scale software systems as mathematical models that you can rigorously reason about. But it's not necessarily easy to translate between real-world systems and textbook models. This talk will cover practical techniques for turning operational data into actionable predictions. We'll show how to use the Universal Scalability Law to develop a model of system performance, and how to leverage that model to make more informed capacity planning and architectural decisions. We'll discuss what data to gather in production to better inform its predictions -- for example, why it's important to capture the shape of a latency distribution, and not just a few percentiles. We'll also talk about some of the limitations and pitfalls of performance modelling.
others.Name: Queueing Theory in Practice: Performance Modeling for the Working Engineer
others.Resource: Queueing Theory in Practice: Performance Modeling for the Working Engineer - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hda5tMrLJqc

others.Description: Havens shares his views on what makes great architecture great. He details what happened when an API call required 23 other synchronous procedures calls to return a correct answer. He discusses the challenges of managing inventory at Walmart, how one implements event sourcing patterns on that scale, and the functional programming principles that it depends upon. Lastly, he talks about how much category theory you need to know to do functional programming and considerations when creating code in complex systems. It is recommended to first watch the talk https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n5S3hScE6dU or listen to the podcast https://itrevolution.com/the-idealcast-episode-22/
others.Name: Simplifying The Inventory Management Systems at the World’s Largest Retailer Using Functional Programming Principles

others.Description: Useful talk for anyway working with legacy complex systems. Younes Zeriahi shares practical examples and techniques for refactoring code in a way that accelerates delivery and improves the overall design, using concepts like Mikado, expand and contract, and Chesterton's Fence. He also highlights the importance of a strong test suite and a deep understanding of the domain for effective refactoring.

others.Description: This presentation is about identifying service boundaries in software architecture to avoid coupling and ending up with a "big ball of mud", even when using microservices. I recommend this talk because it provides practical advice on how to define services as technical authorities for specific business capabilities, leading to more maintainable and scalable systems.

Dan North.Resource: Microservices: Software that Fits in Your Head - http://www.infoq.com/presentations/microservices-replaceability-consistency

Dan North.Description: Dan North and Jessica Kerr make a journey through complexity. At the other side we may find simplicity, or we may find the light at the end of the tunnel is just another oncoming ESB.
Dan North.Name: Complexity is Outside the Code

Dan North.Description: Maybe we've been thinking about delivery all wrong. Maybe features aren’t the point after all. Maybe there are other kinds of work that we should recognise, schedule and track as first class citizens. Maybe this could take some of the uncertainty out of the delivery process, and give us back our sanity. Maybe.
Dan North.Name: Beyond Features: rethinking agile software delivery
Dan North.Resource: Beyond Features: rethinking agile software delivery - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EoJFWdhv8q0

Dan North.Description: The modern developer needs to be constantly reinventing themselves, learning, and helping others to do the same. In this session, Dan explores some of the skills and characteristics of the modern developer, and suggests some ways you can grow them for yourself.
Dan North.Name: Beyond Developer

Dan North.Description: Very good talk about the nature of software development and the approach to the profession. Dan talks about software as a medium, continuous learning, teamwork, etc. Highly recommended.
Dan North.Name: The best programmer I know

Dan North.Description: This podcast features Daniel Terhorst-North, a prominent figure in the software development world, reflecting on 20 years of industry changes and sharing his insights on topics ranging from Agile and DevOps to product management and organizational flow. Drawing on his experiences at Thoughtworks and beyond, Terhorst-North highlights the importance of connecting business needs with technical implementation and emphasizes the value of building evolvable systems with "simplexity" in mind.
Dan North.Name: How to Deliver Quality Software Against All Odds GOTO 2024
Dan North.Resource: How to Deliver Quality Software Against All Odds GOTO 2024 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=klqo1oPdbpM

Jez Humble.Description: A new version of a classic one. A great talk.

Jez Humble.Resource: Continuous Delivery Sounds Great But It Won’t Work Here - https://www.infoq.com/presentations/continuous-delivery-highlights

Jez Humble.Resource: DOES17 London - The Key to High Performance What the Data Says - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cabzxfM_vWE

Jez Humble.Description: A must. Essential for understanding high performance teams and modern agile development.

Jez Humble.Description: Great 2012 presentation on Continuous Delivery. Jez discusses the value of CD to the business. He presents the principles and related practices, including value stream mapping, deployment pipelines, acceptance test-driven development, zero-downtime releases, etc. This talk is a while old, but still as relevant as the first day.
Jez Humble.Name: Continuous Delivery

Jez Humble.Description: In this talk Jez will describe how to implement devops principles and practices, how to overcome typical obstacles, and the outcomes DevOps enables. A must-see talk.
Jez Humble.Name: Industry Keynote: The DevOps Transformation

Jez Humble.Description: Since the Continuous Delivery book came out in 2010, it’s gone from being a controversial idea to a commonplace… until you consider that many people who say they are doing it aren’t really, and there are still plenty of places that consider it crazy talk. In this session Jez will present some of the highlights and lowlights of the past six years listening to people explain why continuous delivery won’t work, and what he learned in the process.
Jez Humble.Name: Continuous Delivery - Sounds Great But It Won't Work Here
Jez Humble.Resource: Continuous Delivery - Sounds Great But It Won't Work Here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IvWr29afDF8

Jez Humble.Description: Jez Humble examines the common pitfalls of scaling Agile methodologies and presents alternative strategies for achieving organizational agility. He argues that simply implementing Agile practices without addressing underlying systemic issues, such as lengthy feedback loops and inefficient decision-making processes, will not lead to significant improvements. Instead, he proposes that organizations focus on creating rapid feedback loops, reducing batch sizes, and adopting an experimental approach to product development and process improvement, emphasizing value over cost and estimation.
Jez Humble.Name: Why Scaling Agile Doesn't Work - GOTO 2015
Jez Humble.Resource: Why Scaling Agile Doesn't Work - GOTO 2015 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?app=desktop&v=2zYxWEZ0gYg

Randy Shoup.Description: A great talk about culture for high-performance tech organizations. Good complement for Accelerate and based in his experience at ebay and google.
Randy Shoup.Name: Building and Scaling a High-Performance Culture
Randy Shoup.Resource: Building and Scaling a High-Performance Culture - https://www.infoq.com/presentations/autonomy-trust-pragmacy-teams/

Randy Shoup.Description: This talk explores how attitude impacts success, focusing on growth mindset, trust, and confidence. It emphasizes the importance of continuous improvement, psychological safety, and overcoming the impostor phenomenon.
Randy Shoup.Name: Attitude Determines Altitude- Engineering Yourself

Randy Shoup.Description: Great presentation, in which Randy, starts from the 5 ideals of the Unicorn project (Locality and Simplicity, Focus, Flow, and Joy, Improvement of Daily Work, Psychological Safety, Customer Focus) to describe what we can do as technical leaders and as engineers to improve our ability to build and deliver software.
Randy Shoup.Name: Improving Software Flow

Randy Shoup.Description: Great summary about the different ways high-performing engineering organizations gain leverage by specialization and sharing.
Randy Shoup.Name: Engineering Your Organization: Services, Platforms, and Communities
Randy Shoup.Resource: Engineering Your Organization: Services, Platforms, and Communities - https://www.infoq.com/presentations/engineering-organization-services-platforms-communities/

Randy Shoup.Description: A very interesting session about eBay's strategy to improve delivery performance. A great example of engineering leadership.
Randy Shoup.Name: Driving a Tech-led Reimagination of eBay Through DevOps (US 2021)
Randy Shoup.Resource: Driving a Tech-led Reimagination of eBay Through DevOps (US 2021) - https://videos.itrevolution.com/watch/624410229/

Randy Shoup.Description: This talk discusses the cultural change required to adopt a devops mentality. Excellent advice and warnings derived from Randy's experience leading teams at eBay, Google, and KIXEYE.
Randy Shoup.Name: Ten (Hard-Won) Lessons of the DevOps Transition
Randy Shoup.Resource: Ten (Hard-Won) Lessons of the DevOps Transition - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6tREbJl8e_Y

Randy Shoup.Description: In this session, Randy explains how they improve the overall flow and the engineering capacity following the ideas in the Unicorn Project (Locality and Simplicity, Focus, Flow, and Joy, Improvement of Daily Work, Psychological Safety, and Customer Focus). It is an excellent talk about generating/improving an engineering culture following lean principles.
Randy Shoup.Name: Improving Software Flow

Gojko Adzic.Description: Great talks about how cloud is changing the risk profile of our application and the software quality practices.
Gojko Adzic.Name: Snow White and the 777.777.777 Dwarfs

Gojko Adzic.Description: An essential talk to understand how to get the most impact with the least amount of software (and thereby reduce basal cost and time to market). Highly recommended.
Gojko Adzic.Name: Make Impacts Not Software

Gojko Adzic.Description: Gojko presents very interesting examples of developments that have achieved very good impacts (by minifying the developed software). He also explains the use of the impact mapping technique, which is very useful for focusing on the impact.
Gojko Adzic.Name: Fast-track from Idea to Impact

Gojko Adzic.Description: Gojko gives a masterclass on how to focus on impacts, understand the need, and improve product decisions. Good ideas to postpone decisions, focus on behavioral changes, and be cautious with metrics. An essential talk for any product developer.
Gojko Adzic.Name: Adaptive Planning Beyond User Stories

Gojko Adzic.Description: Gojko Adzic describes why independent testing should be a thing of the past. He explains how testers engaging with developers and business users create opportunities to accomplish things they cannot do otherwise.
Gojko Adzic.Name: Oredev 2011: Sleeping with the enemy

Jessica Kerr.Description: Dan North and Jessica Kerr make a journey through complexity. At the other side we may find simplicity, or we may find the light at the end of the tunnel is just another oncoming ESB.
Jessica Kerr.Name: Complexity is Outside the Code

Jessica Kerr.Description: The journey of a software developer is a climb through abstraction: algorithms, patterns, architecture.... How do we keep expanding scope, without losing focus on the real work? Join us for a journey into the fourth dimension, where we don't just change code; we design change.
Jessica Kerr.Name: KEYNOTE Designing change

Jessica Kerr.Description: This was an excellent talk, full of insights that prompted reflection. In this talk Jessica looks at how the shared mental models created while mob programming work throughout the team even when they are not actively mobbing. She also explores the other practices she’s found complementary in creating a high functioning team and how looking at your contribution from a generative (helping other create) vs a productive (what I created, myself) frame can lead to a happier, better and more productive team.
Jessica Kerr.Name: Shared Mental Models Part 1

Jessica Kerr.Description: Great explanation of how system thinking arises and its basic concepts. System thinking is a fundamental tool to work with/in complex systems such as software systems.
Jessica Kerr.Name: Systems Thinking for Developers

Charity Majors.Description: A great talk about the need for testing in production and the approach we can use.
Charity Majors.Name: Yes, I Test in Production (And So Do You)
Charity Majors.Resource: Yes, I Test in Production (And So Do You) - https://www.infoq.com/presentations/testing-production-2018

Charity Majors.Description: A ton of useful insights and ideas in this excellent Charity presentation. Great description of observability and its need in modern systems.
Charity Majors.Name: What got you here won't get you there: How your team can become a high-performing team by embracing observability
Charity Majors.Resource: What got you here won't get you there: How your team can become a high-performing team by embracing observability - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QK6zEFdvXYw

Charity Majors.Description: This talk describe the social and technical strategies that great teams all of the world are using to be happier, more productive and make their users happy too.
Charity Majors.Name: The Sociotechnical Path to High-Performing Teams
Charity Majors.Resource: The Sociotechnical Path to High-Performing Teams - https://vimeo.com/723450508

Charity Majors.Description: Fun and interesting talk about the context and process for making technical decisions. Very good ideas. The talk is a few years old, but the ideas are still very valid. Charity talks about how to decide to introduce new technologies, the cost of maintaining them, the importance of migrations, failure modes, etc.
Charity Majors.Name: A Young Lady's Illustrated Primer to Technical Decision-Making
Charity Majors.Resource: A Young Lady's Illustrated Primer to Technical Decision-Making - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PSIPhVjWBO0

Dave Farley.Description: A must. Essential for understanding high performance teams and modern agile development.
Dave Farley.Name: What Will The Next 10 Years Of Continuous Delivery Look Like?
Dave Farley.Resource: What Will The Next 10 Years Of Continuous Delivery Look Like? - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FVEWdatM8Uk

Dave Farley.Description: One of the best descriptions I have heard of the usefulness of this practice. Dave provides pair programming examples, describes some pair programming best practices, and challenges some thinking about pair programming patterns and anti-patterns.
Dave Farley.Name: You Must Be CRAZY To Do Pair Programming
Dave Farley.Resource: You Must Be CRAZY To Do Pair Programming - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aItVJprLYkg

Dave Farley.Description: Essential 5-minute video. In this video Dave Farley explains the difference and why the two are largely mutually exclusive, and then explains how to live in the CI world by describing three different approaches to keeping the software working as it evolves.
Dave Farley.Name: Continuous Integration vs Feature Branch Workflow
Dave Farley.Resource: Continuous Integration vs Feature Branch Workflow - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v4Ijkq6Myfc

Dave Farley.Description: A must-see talk. Dave Farley describes 8 common mistakes that junior developers often make and offers his advice on how to avoid them. Whatever your approach to software engineering and software development, whether you are practicing Continuous Delivery, DevOps, or something else, we think that you may find some helpful ideas in this video.
Dave Farley.Name: Avoid These Common Mistakes Junior Developers Make
Dave Farley.Resource: Avoid These Common Mistakes Junior Developers Make - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JL1lMPxR7KQ

GeePaw Hill.Description: A must-talk for anyone trying to do lean/agile software development. The talk delves into the reasons why the strategy of using small, safe steps is the right one to steadily evolve a software system. I am very much aligned with this approach to software development.
GeePaw Hill.Name: Want More Value Faster? Take Many More Much Smaller Steps
GeePaw Hill.Resource: Want More Value Faster? Take Many More Much Smaller Steps - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1mOs1_pvS9A

GeePaw Hill.Description: A great talk for anyone trying to do lean/agile software development. Explain why we need to give small safe steps (3s). Very interesting Q&A session at the end.
GeePaw Hill.Name: GeePaw Hill "More Smaller Steps"

GeePaw Hill.Description: Good conversation about GeePaw Hill's software development approach based on taking continuous small safe steps (Many More Much Smaller Steps).
GeePaw Hill.Name: Many More Much Smaller Steps with GeePaw Hill
GeePaw Hill.Resource: Many More Much Smaller Steps with GeePaw Hill - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lHoOUylvfxQ

GeePaw Hill.Description: Pure wisdom on why working in small, safe steps is the most efficient way to work in software product development when we have environments of high uncertainty (which is almost always).
GeePaw Hill.Name: GeePaw Hill on Incremental Software Delivery
GeePaw Hill.Resource: GeePaw Hill on Incremental Software Delivery - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NDXV16uheNs

Marty Cagan.Description: An open discussion on Modern Product Management.  The talk contains a lot of interesting discussions during the Q&A. I think it covers all the underpinnings of modern product management.
Marty Cagan.Name: The Marty Cagan special - ProductTank #27 Singapore
Marty Cagan.Resource: The Marty Cagan special - ProductTank #27 Singapore - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=idMN-YwiYOs

Marty Cagan.Description: A great presentation on skilled product teams and leading product organizations. The questions at the end are also very interesting.
Marty Cagan.Name: Master Class with Marty Cagan

Adrian Cockcroft.Description: A good summary of how accelerating the iteration pace is fundamental for innovation and how the cloud can help with it.
Adrian Cockcroft.Name: Digital Transformation

Adrian Cockcroft.Description: Interesting talk about how to use the cloud and how it enables innovation.
Adrian Cockcroft.Name: Speeding Up Innovation

Adrian Cockcroft.Description: A classic talk to understand how to leverage the cloud, continuous delivery and devops to create modern web-scale systems.
Adrian Cockcroft.Name: Velocity and Volume or Speed Wins
Adrian Cockcroft.Resource: Velocity and Volume or Speed Wins - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wyWI3gLpB8o

Henrik Kniberg.Description: As usualy Henrik deliver a great talk that inspired me a lot.
Henrik Kniberg.Name: AgileByExample 2016: Henrik Kniberg - Keynote - Focus (or Stop Starting, Start Finishing)
Henrik Kniberg.Resource: AgileByExample 2016: Henrik Kniberg - Keynote - Focus (or Stop Starting, Start Finishing) - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n7wH2XdOWpM

Henrik Kniberg.Description: Henrik Kniberg explains the resource utilization trap, how it impacts our ability to deliver and what we can do about it.
Henrik Kniberg.Name: The resource utilization trap

Henrik Kniberg.Description: Brilliant explanation of the concept of WIP and how limiting it improves delivery flow.
Henrik Kniberg.Name: Multiple WIP vs One Piece Flow Example
Henrik Kniberg.Resource: Multiple WIP vs One Piece Flow Example - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yqi9Gwt-OEA

Kent Beck.Description: Very deep ideas about how to make any kind of huge technical change using small and incremental changes. This part of the core of agile... Vertical slicing to make changes in small (low risk) steps.
Kent Beck.Name: Big Transitions in Small Steps

Kent Beck.Description: Great talk about the human relationships generated during software development. Kent explains these relations and uses them to analyze the development flow, the need for small safe steps, and the tension generated between the people involved. For me, this talk is a must.
Kent Beck.Name: Tidy First?

Kent Beck.Description: Interesting presentation about software design and trade-offs and techniques to refactor the code before applying a change. The talk is full of interesting insights. It is also very interesting the Q&A part that is not only focused on the content of the talk.
Kent Beck.Name: Code for Ukraine #2: Tidy First? Daily Empirical Software Design & Why It Works
Kent Beck.Resource: Code for Ukraine #2: Tidy First? Daily Empirical Software Design & Why It Works - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VrkRAVX1h4I

Christin Gorman.Description: Simplicity--the art of maximizing the amount of work not done--is essential. Great talk on how to focus on the essentials and make simple solutions.
Christin Gorman.Name: From initial request to software in production in 3 weeks
Christin Gorman.Resource: From initial request to software in production in 3 weeks - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RjAXEOIfkq8

Christin Gorman.Description: Great lightning talk, provocative and inspiring.
Christin Gorman.Name: Hibernate should be to programmers what cake mixes are to bakers: beneath their dignity.
Christin Gorman.Resource: Hibernate should be to programmers what cake mixes are to bakers: beneath their dignity. - https://vimeo.com/28885655

Christin Gorman.Description: Inspiring lightning talk about the importance of humanities, empathy for users and information management as the basis of our profession (beyond pure technology and knowledge about logic or mathematics).
Christin Gorman.Name: What makes a good developer
Christin Gorman.Resource: What makes a good developer - https://vimeo.com/748032161

Sandro Mancuso.Description: another version  (NEWCRAFTS Conferences Paris). A very interesting for any developer, product manager o business person. Technics to understand the whole picture for a system and help to define the design from the outside. A good approach for domain modeling.
Sandro Mancuso.Name: A Case for Outside-In Design

Sandro Mancuso.Description: In this live coding session, Sandro will present many techniques that will help you to efficiently retrofit tests to legacy code and then refactor it to show the business logic more clearly.
Sandro Mancuso.Name: Testing and Refactoring Legacy Code

Greg Young.Description: Interesting talk to understand some concepts about simplicity and hiden accidental complexity.
Greg Young.Name: Keynote: 8 Lines of Code

Greg Young.Description: Some good points about the easy evolution of a system when the services are small enough to be understandables and to be rewritten without fear.
Greg Young.Name: The art of destroying software

Mary Poppendieck.Description: Optimizing for speed, flow, and waste reduction. Lean Software Development
Mary Poppendieck.Name: Competing On The Basis Of Speed
Mary Poppendieck.Resource: Competing On The Basis Of Speed - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZSdsjpCcpFw

Mary Poppendieck.Description:
Great talk with the evolution of our field from a lean perspective. Great insights about the engineering role, agile, the current painful division between business and development, how we can think about complex systems, the failure of having proxy roles as the product owner, etc... Great talk, lot of computer and development history, and great Q&A session.
Slides: <https://speakerdeck.com/devopslx/2020-dot-07-meetup-talk-may-poppendieck-six-decades-of-software-engineering>
Mary Poppendieck.Name: Six Decades of Software Engineering

Rich Hickey.Description: 2011\. Great talk and a good excuse to study functional programming.
Rich Hickey.Name: Simple Made Easy

Rich Hickey.Description: This is a 12-minute redux of the 1-hour talk by Rich Hickey, for really impatient people. Original: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SxdOUGdseq4
Rich Hickey.Name: "Simple Made Easy" (12-minute redux) by Rich Hickey (2011)
Rich Hickey.Resource: "Simple Made Easy" (12-minute redux) by Rich Hickey (2011) - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F87PtAoJNtg

Greg Burrell.Description: Greg Burrell presents Netflix’s journey from siloed teams to their Full Cycle Developer model for building and operating their services at Netflix. He discusses the various approaches they’ve tried, the motivations that pushed them to keep evolving, and the lessons learned along the way.
Greg Burrell.Name: Full Cycle Developers @Netflix

Greg Burrell.Description: This talk presents Netflix' journey from siloed teams to our Full Cycle Developer model for building and operating our services at Netflix. Greg discusses the various approaches they’ve tried, the motivations that pushed them to keep evolving, and the lessons learned along the way.
Greg Burrell.Name: Full Cycle Developers at Netflix

John Cutler.Description: Excellent talk. John presents all the learnings he had during the last three years, using his great article as a starting point (<https://cutle.fish/blog/12-signs-youre-working-in-a-feature-factory>). Lots of knowledge and tips to introduce product thinking.
John Cutler.Name: Product Tank Madrid: Focus on Impact with John Cutler - World Product Day 2020
John Cutler.Resource: Product Tank Madrid: Focus on Impact with John Cutler - World Product Day 2020 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7yiudST4bJY

John Cutler.Description: John Cutler, Product Evangelist at Amplitude explains why most of a product developers time is spent waiting and how limiting work in progress, the scope of work and handoffs can increase flow and value.
John Cutler.Name: Creating Value and Flow in Product Development
John Cutler.Resource: Creating Value and Flow in Product Development - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NGdx-f-aGXs

James Shore.Description: Modern software development welcomes changing requirements, even late in the process, but how can we write our software so that those changes don’t create a mess? Evolutionary design is the key. It’s a technique that emerges from Extreme Programming, the method that brought us test-driven development, merciless refactoring, and continuous integration. James Shore first encountered Extreme Programming and evolutionary design nearly 20 years ago. Initially skeptical, he’s explored its boundaries ever since. In this session, James will share what he’s learned through in-depth animations of real software projects. You’ll see how designs evolve over time and you’ll learn how and when to use evolutionary design for your own projects. Part 2: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wDZCF8jfeMc
James Shore.Name: YOW! 2019 Evolutionary Design Animated (Part1)

James Shore.Description: The second part of this great talk. Part1 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LtBRvsez8DI
James Shore.Name: YOW! 2019 Evolutionary Design Animated (Part2)

J.B. Rainsberger.Description: Short excellent talk (7:26') that distilled the essence of software development and agile development. Essential. A must.
J.B. Rainsberger.Name: 7 minutes, 26 seconds, and the Fundamental Theorem of Agile Software Development
J.B. Rainsberger.Resource: 7 minutes, 26 seconds, and the Fundamental Theorem of Agile Software Development - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WSes_PexXcA

J.B. Rainsberger.Description: Integrated tests are a scam. You’re probably writing 2-5% of the integrated tests you need to test thoroughly. You’re probably duplicating unit tests all over the place. Your integrated tests probably duplicate each other all over the place. When an integrated test fails, who knows what’s broken? Integrated tests probably do you more harm than good. Learn the two-pronged attack that solves the problem: collaboration tests and contract tests.
J.B. Rainsberger.Name: Integrated Tests Are A Scam
J.B. Rainsberger.Resource: Integrated Tests Are A Scam - https://vimeo.com/80533536

Donald Reinertsen.Description:
An introduction to Lean Product Development Flow given by Don Reinertsen at Adventures with Agile in London. 
This talk is a must to understand modern product development (Flow, uncertainty, Little's law, cost of delay, the value of feedback, queues, batch size, etc).
Donald Reinertsen.Name: Second Generation Lean Product Development Flow
Donald Reinertsen.Resource: Second Generation Lean Product Development Flow - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L6v6W7jkwok

Donald Reinertsen.Description: This talk explores key concepts and mathematical principles behind achieving flow in processes, like product development, drawing parallels to flow dynamics in traffic and internet systems. Don Reinertsen explains the economics of queuing, batch size reduction, and fast feedback loops, highlighting their impact on cycle time and overall process efficiency.
Donald Reinertsen.Name: The Logic of Flow: Some Indispensable Concepts
Donald Reinertsen.Resource: The Logic of Flow: Some Indispensable Concepts - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rc1MqHsiiKo

Sandi Metz.Description: This talk strips away the veil and offers simple, practical guidelines for choosing what to test and how to test it. Finding the right testing balance isn't magic, it's a magic trick; come and learn the secret of writing stable tests that protect your application at the lowest possible cost.
Sandi Metz.Name: Rails Conf 2013 The Magic Tricks of Testing
Sandi Metz.Resource: Rails Conf 2013 The Magic Tricks of Testing - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=URSWYvyc42M

Sandi Metz.Description: This talk strips away the well-known design principles and exposes the hidden, underlying goals of design. It reveals programming techniques that allow you to write less code while creating beautiful, flexible applications.
Sandi Metz.Name: Less - The Path to Better Design
Sandi Metz.Resource: Less - The Path to Better Design - https://vimeo.com/53154357
